docs.snippet: How close did the Italian hero come to leading the Union army? Very.
docs.lead_paragraph: The tiny Mediterranean island of Caprera, near Sardinia, was not the sort of place to find an American diplomat in the late summer of 1861, but that's precisely where Henry Shelton Sanford landed late in the afternoon of Sept. 8. It had been a long, involved trip: he came from Brussels to Genoa by train, secretly chartered a ship to avoid public notice and, on the night of Sept. 7, sailed through the Ligurian Sea to Sardinia. Landing late the next day, he hired a small boat to take him to Caprera, then walked more than a mile on a narrow path across the rocky, windswept island.
docs.abstract: How close did the Italian hero come to leading the Union army? Very.

docs.snippet: Burdened by slowing consumer spending at home, Wal-Mart Stores sought another jolt to its sales.     The world's biggest retailer turned its eyes to a continent where it has little presence: Africa. Wal-Mart announced last fall that it would seek to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Burdened by slowing consumer spending at home, Wal-Mart Stores sought another jolt to its sales. The world's biggest retailer turned its eyes to a continent where it has little presence: Africa. Wal-Mart announced last fall that it would seek to buy Massmart, its closest counterpart in sub-Saharan Africa, and this year it won approval to buy half of the retailer for $2.4 billion.

headline.main: Untapped and Growing, Frontier Markets Beckon

byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

docs.snippet: The new antidote to civilization is a squatters' community in Uruguay where modern conveniences are few, but good vibes abound.
docs.abstract: The new antidote to civilization is a squatters' community in Uruguay where modern conveniences are few, but good vibes abound.

docs.snippet: The new antidote to civilization is a squatters' community in Uruguay where modern conveniences are few, but good vibes abound.
docs.lead_paragraph: Cabo Polonio, a remote beach village in southeastern Uruguay, sits on a green peninsula between the Atlantic and a desert landscape of shifting sand dunes. Strewn across the grassy promontory are a single lighthouse and a few hundred whimsical dwellings. Rasta-colored flags serve as wind vanes, tinted glass bottles are embedded in walls, and exteriors are painted with pictures of suns, cow spots, rainbows and a Klimt-like rendering of a woman. One stands out as particularly fanciful. It's more sculpture than cabin, constructed from panes of glass, wood, plastic, bamboo blinds and green plexiglass, with tall, lush plants growing out of the floor.
docs.abstract: The new antidote to civilization is a squatters' community in Uruguay where modern conveniences are few, but good vibes abound.

docs.snippet: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map.
docs.abstract: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map.

docs.snippet: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map.
docs.lead_paragraph: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map, visiting an 18th-century fantasy in Chicago, a contemporary art-filled aerie in Manhattan, a supernatural lighting installation in Munich and an off-the-grid vacation spot in Uruguay. It also recalls a chronicler of California Modern architecture and a young London designer who performs alchemy on unlikely materials. See all the stories here.
docs.abstract: The fall issue of T Design goes all over the map.

docs.snippet: Cabo Polonio, a remote beach village in southeastern Uruguay, sits on a green peninsula between the Atlantic and a desert landscape of shifting sand dunes. Strewn across the grassy promontory are a single lighthouse and a few hundred whimsical...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cabo Polonio, a remote beach village in southeastern Uruguay, sits on a green peninsula between the Atlantic and a desert landscape of shifting sand dunes. Strewn across the grassy promontory are a single lighthouse and a few hundred whimsical dwellings. Rasta-colored flags serve as wind vanes, tinted glass bottles are embedded in walls, and exteriors are painted with pictures of suns, cow spots, rainbows and a Klimt-like rendering of a woman. One stands out as particularly fanciful. It's more sculpture than cabin, constructed from panes of glass, wood, plastic, bamboo blinds and green plexiglass, with tall, lush plants growing out of the floor. On a recent visit to the village, I knocked on its door to find Omar Santiago, a scruffy Uruguayan in his late 20s, arranging to rent the house to a Chilean couple. ''I'm not a hippie,'' he said, pointing to his ringing phone. ''Look here, a business call.'' When his place is rented, Santiago later explained, he sleeps in a tent he keeps pitched on the beach. I asked him if he owned his plot, and a playful smile crept across his face. ''Yes and no,'' he said.
